Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Small Businesses and Access to Legal Resources During the COVID-19 Pandemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely affected businesses of all sizes, particularly small business entrepreneurs. In addition to economic harms, small businesses often lack access to legal resources that would help them navigate issues raised by the pandemic and assist in economic recovery. This project will examine small business’ access to legal advice by generating knowledge about legal challenges they face. As well, this research will assess the effectiveness of different methods of disseminating legal information to small businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic. <br/><br/>This project will incorporate a mixed-methods approach to study small business’ ability to access legal resources during times of economic turmoil. First, the project will employ interview and survey techniques to generate data from small business owners across different demographic groups and industries regarding legal issues they face. Second, using an experimental design the project will examine randomized interventions designed to provide legal information through low-cost means that enable self-help to small business entrepreneurs who lack representation. Findings will provide insight into the ability of small business entrepreneurs to utilize and understand the law during the COVID-19 pandemic.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: RAPID: Small Businesses and Access to Legal Resources During the COVID-19 Pandemic
PI: Jeremy McClane
Co-PIs: Melissa Graebner, Robert Lawless, Verity Winship
Federal Award ID: 2037350

Objectives of the research

The objectives of this project were to better understand the needs of small businesses during the pandemic, with a focus on the ways in which small business owners use the law and legal professionals. The pandemic intensified many pre-existing challenges that small businesses face and created new ones, but also created new opportunities for some businesses. Our goal was to understand when and how the law and lawyers are helpful for these issues, both in normal times and times of crisis, as well as when business owners do not find them helpful. This, in turn, adds to the body of knowledge available to the legal academy and practicing attorneys on how to best provide legal services.  

Work carried out

Our team conducted 96 in-depth interviews lasting between 30 minutes and one hour with a wide range of small business owners throughout the state. We used a semi-structured format, with a set of interview questions that interviewers followed but from which they were able to deviate if needed. From this, we gleaned what the major impacts were on small business owners in Illinois from the COVID-19 pandemic.  In addition, we collected in-depth survey results from nearly 900 Illinois small business owners. Finally, we conducted a field experiment involving 120 small business entrepreneurs in the state. The results fell into two major categories, described below.

Legal and policy needs of small businesses: Gaps between perception and reality

Using interviews and a detailed survey of 900 Illinois small business owners, we ask whether the legal profession?s well-intentioned advice effectively helped small businesses with their most pressing problems. We find that is unlikely to have been the case. We find that models of small businesses upon which legal advice and policy proposal are based sometimes fit poorly with reality on the ground. This is the case in two respects. First, legal professionals often think about small businesses as just scaled-down large corporations. Thus, in the pandemic, some assumed that small businesses would face the same legal issues but perhaps just not with as many zeroes after the dollar sign. The idea that these are just ?small big businesses? may have contributed to a blind spot in addressing the needs of this population: the assumption that small businesses do not pose the same concerns as consumer households. However, small businesses and their owners fall in a middle ground between the world of business and world of consumer households. Legal advice and policy prescriptions need to account for this in normal times and times of crisis. Second, business practices often do not reflect the formal legal contractual relationships that are on paper. Contracting parties frequently ignore or modify written contract terms because of social norms, commercial customs, a concern for relationships or reputation, or out of compassion, trust, or a sense of decency. This can occur as a result of the occurrence of new circumstances, or as a result of a common understanding that a given community or industry will abide by extra-contractual commitments. This is a conceptual gap that needs to be addressed in the academy and by the bar.

The role of uncertainty in legal advice seeking during a crisis

Using data from 96 in-depth interviews and a randomized experiment with 168 participants, we show that people in states of deep uncertainty?commonly experienced during times of crisis?are one third as likely to perceive lawyers as providing a good option for solving legal problems compared to others. A rich literature addresses decision-making under uncertainty and distinguishes between deep uncertainty and calculable risk. The literature has, however, overlooked how people make decisions to seek legal advice, which are critical for access to justice. These results have real-world implications. Uncertainty likely prevented many small business owners from seeking legal advice during the Covid-19 crisis that would have helped during a critical time. This finding can improve the ways in which legal help is provided to individuals and to small businesses, which are economically important and vulnerable to shocks.
